page.title: 06Ecology
page.content: The lynch,a wooded bank left by medieval ploughing,with coppices and hedgerows surounding most fields provide shelter and movement for wildlife. Seven or eight badger setts lie above the Lynch near White Farm.Others are reported from the South-Western corner of the area.One badger killed on the A258 in 1985 weighed twenty-eight pounds. Foxes are sighted crossing the A258 or in Kingsdown village gardens.Rabbits are less frequent.Swallows nest under eaves of local buldings,including the school.Kestrels,Swifts,Wood pigeons, Collar doves,Finches,Magpies,etc are seen.Sea-shore:-Herring gulls,Black- headed gulls and Shag.On uncultivated patches along hedgerows and on the Free Down,native wild flowers are still found in considerable variety.
